title: NLCS preview: Surprise matchup pits Cardinals and Nationals with World Series trip on the line
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: USA TODAY Sports' Steve Gardner previews the NLCS showdown between the Washington Nationals and St. Louis Cardinals. USA TODAY

ST. LOUIS — This National League Championship Series isn’t so much a battle for the pennant as it is an antidote to Major League Baseball’s numbing predictivity.

Tired of a landscape that produced 10 90-game losers, more than half the playoff field returning intact and a slew of front offices potentially too smart for the game’s competitive good?

Cast your eyes toward the Washington Nationals and St. Louis Cardinals, then, and behold a pair of teams that didn’t exactly shock the baseball world – but undeniably jolted its modern hierarchy.

As Friday’s Game 1 approaches, these teams may well regard the other and ask, "Just what are you doing here?"

They arrive on the highest highs, surviving Game 5 Division Series in fashions befitting their unforeseen rises. The Nationals erased their second eighth-inning deficit in an elimination game in eight days to stun the 106-win Los Angeles Dodgers with a three-homer barrage in a 9-5, 10-inning win.

Ten was a lucky number for the Cardinals, too – their record-setting run total in the first inning of their Game 5 throttling of an Atlanta Braves team that finished four games ahead of the Nationals in the NL East, relegating Washington to wild-card status.

Kolten Wong turns a double play as Trea Turner slides in during a game at Busch Stadium in September. (Photo: Jeff Curry, USA TODAY Sports)

Those facts are now happily irrelevant, as the Nationals are on a staggering 78-40 run since their famously grim 19-31 start and advanced past the NLDS for the first time in five tries.

So, too, is the Cardinals’ third-place standing as late as Aug. 7, before they finished on a 33-16 run to end the Cubs’ five-year playoff run and bypass defending NL Central champ Milwaukee, too.

Now, it is a matchup of two gloriously flawed teams, Washington pitting its three aces and shaky bullpen against St. Louis’ Cy Young stud, uneven offense and NL-best relief corps. What next?

Foolish as it may be to forecast these clubs’ next moves, here’s what could go down:

For starters

Projected rotations

Game 1: RHP Anibal Sanchez (11-8, 3.85 ERA) vs. RHP Miles Mikolas (9-14, 4.16)

Game 2: RHP Max Scherzer (11-7, 2.92 ERA) vs. RHP Adam Wainwright (14-10, 4.19)

Game 3: Stephen Strasburg (18-6, 3.32) vs. RHP Jack Flaherty (11-8, 2.75)

Game 4: Patrick Corbin (14-7, 3.25) vs. RHP Dakota Hudson (16-7, 3.35)

After the timely off days and best-of-five NLDS format, both rotations will be forced to stretch out a bit more in this best-of-seven. At least initially.

Game 3 will be the one to watch, as Cy Young candidates Strasburg and Flaherty square off in a game that will either put a club up 2-1 or down 3-0. Should the Nationals lose that one, manager Dave Martinez may have to ponder bringing Scherzer back on three days’ rest in Game 5. For now, Martinez won’t commit to a rotation beyond Sanchez in Game 1.

ALCS: Houston gives the people want they want – an Astros-Yankees showdown

NATIONALS: Zimmerman credits Strasburg's 2012 shutdown

The Nationals’ front four account for some $550 million in guaranteed money and certainly earned it this month, with Strasburg making a crucial bullpen appearance in the Nationals wild-card game comeback and Scherzer and Corbin combining for three relief appearances in the NLDS.

But the Cardinals’ quartet was even better in quieting a dominant Atlanta offense, holding the Braves to a .214 batting average, pitching to a 1.78 ERA with a 28-8 strikeout-walk ratio.

“I think it's going to make for some really exciting October baseball,” Mikolas said Thursday. “You've got Cy Young award winners, guys who are probably going to win Cy Young awards, all stars, franchise icons, I mean, the list goes on and on.”

The Cardinals will need to be just as precise against the Nationals.

Checkers and chess

The Cardinals just matched up with a Braves lineup that was dangerous from both sides of the plate and alternated right- and left-handed batters from one through eight.

Washington poses a similar challenge through its first five spots, from power-speed leadoff demon Trea Turner all the way through Game 5 grand slam hero Howie Kendrick. And lurking in the 3-4 hole are the for now unstoppable Anthony Rendon and Juan Soto.

Rendon, perpetually overshadowed, got the go-ahead single in a Game 4 win and started the Game 5 tying rally with a homer off Clayton Kershaw – followed by a Soto blast a pitch later.

Rendon and Soto are a combined 13 for 42 (.310) this postseason, with on-base percentages of .385 and .423, respectively. They will pose a particularly difficult matchup in the late innings – just watch how the Dodgers bungled that in Game 5 – and magnify the import of lefty reliever Andrew Miller, who pitched a pair of hitless innings in the NLDS.

“They're tough because they're plate-disciplined more than anything. They’re not going to help you out,” says Cardinals catcher Matt Wieters, who spent 2017-18 with the Nationals. “It’s about executing.”

The Nationals, meanwhile, may need to re-think their bullpen usage. They’ve preferred using erstwhile closer Sean Doolittle in the eighth and Daniel Hudson in the ninth of late, which worked out well against the Dodgers, as the southpaw Doolittle matched up well against their lefty-heavy lineup.

But should it be tight and close in the seventh or eighth innings, the Nationals may want to consider tabbing Hudson earlier to attack righty-swinging Paul Goldschmidt, Marcell Ozuna and Paul DeJong, who combined for 93 homers in the regular season and four in the NLDS.

Keep an eye on

Dave Martinez: The Nationals manager pushed almost all the right buttons in the NLDS, ultimately outmaneuvering more celebrated Dodgers counterpart Dave Roberts. He intentionally put the tying run on base in Game 2 and lived to tell about it, while his relief gambit with Scherzer that same game locked down a must win. After the Dodgers wore down Strasburg in Game 5, Martinez stole just enough outs from Tanner Rainey and Corbin – who rebounded from a Game 3 relief disaster – to preserve trusted relievers Daniel Hudson and Sean Doolittle for the ninth and 10th innings. Martinez was much maligned in his first year as Nationals manager and seemingly on the hot seat after their poor start this season but is running these playoff games with conviction – and his players are responding in kind.

Adam Wainwright: At 38, Wainwright is not the dominant dude who took star turns as a closer and ace on Cardinals World Series championship teams in 2006 and 2011. Yet he proved in Game 3 of the NLDS that he can still carry them when it counts, holding Atlanta to four hits over 7 ⅔ innings and 120 pitches. Now, he’ll match up at least once with Scherzer, and with Cards ace Flaherty perhaps neutralized by Strasburg in Game 3, Wainwright will probably need to outpitch Scherzer at some point or St. Louis is in trouble.

In the end

It’s tempting to call this series a coin flip, but then again, coin flips are relatively easy to forecast. All signs point to a tightly-pitched, well played and possibly low-scoring series. It’s hard to side against the Nationals’ mojo, particularly after they’ve run off three wins in elimination games already.

But the Cardinals put together an excellent pitching plan against the Braves and have the horses to cool the Nationals’ simmering bats. Throw in superior marks in the bullpen and defensively, and it’s enough little things that add up to the smallest of advantages.

Cardinals in 6.
description: After thrilling series in the last round, the Cardinals and Nationals face off in the National League Championship Series.
